metadata.titleEn: In-situ measurement data set of the soil moisture and temperature wireless sensor network within the Shandian River Basin (2020)
metadata.description:
This data set contains in-situ measurements of soil moisture, soil temperature, and precipitation at 34 stations from a wireless Soil Moisture Network within the ShanDian River basin (referred to as the SMN-SDR hereafter). The coverage of the entire network is about 10,000 km2 (115.5-116.5°E, 41.5-42.5°N). The topography of the SMN-SDR is relatively flat, and land surfaces are typically dominated by grasslands and croplands. A total of 34 stations are set up in the network with three sampling scales including 100 km (large scale), 50 km (medium scale), and 10 km (small scale). The soil moisture sensors used are Decagon 5TM with five measuring depths (3, 5, 10, 20, and 50 cm) installed for each station. Of the 34 stations, there are 20 stations equipped with HOBO rain gauges. Undisturbed soil samples at each layer of soil for each station were taken to analyze the gravimetric/volumetric water content, bulk density, and soil texture for further specific calibration. The power supply is provided by solar panels and all data can be transmitted wirelessly to a server. The sampling interval of the data recording time is 10 (before June 2019) or 15 minutes (after June 2019).
This network can improve the comprehensive observation capabilities of key water cycle parameters in the ShanDian River basin and provide long-term ground reference data for satellite- and model-based soil moisture products.
metadata.instructions:
File naming: The in-situ measurement data set of the SMN-SDR is stored in csv format, and the file name is: "ShandianRiver_XY_5TM/HOBO_SM/TS/PP_xxcm_YYYY-MM-DD_YYYY-MM-DD.csv".
where, X represents the sampling scales, usually “L” (100km) or “M” (50km), or “S” (10km); Y stands for site number; 5TM/HOBO stands for sensor type, for example, the sensor for soil moisture and soil temperature data is 5TM, and the sensor for precipitation observation is HOBO; SM/TS/PP represents the type of in-situ data, SM is soil moisture, TS is soil temperature, and PP is precipitation; xxcm represents the detection depth, usually "03cm", "05cm", "10cm", "20cm", "50cm". Note that when the measurement data is precipitation, xxcm does not display. YYYY-MM-DD_YYYY-MM-DD represents the start and end time of the in-situ data.
Data reading method: The data set can be directly opened with a text program (such as notepad or excel).

background: Soil moisture is a key element of the terrestrial water cycle, controlling various hydrological, ecological, and biogeochemical processes. The acquisition of accurate surface soil moisture data is critical for many applications, including drought monitoring, crop yield estimation, flood prediction, and heat-wave forecasting. Considering the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, point-scale in situ measurements can only obtain precise information over a very small area. Accordingly, in situ measurements are usually too sparse to specifically describe the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales. To meet research and application needs, various global-scale soil moisture products have been developed, which can be roughly divided into the following three major groups: (1) Remotely sensed soil moisture directly retrieved from active/passive satellite microwave observations. Microwave remote sensing, especially passive microwave, has become an effective way to estimate soil moisture at large scales due to its strong sensitivity to soil moisture, as well as the advantages of short-term access and all-weather monitoring. Several satellite platforms carrying passive/active microwave sensors have been successfully operated for the past decades, including (but not limited to) low-frequency passive microwave sensors such as SMOS (Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity) and SMAP (Soil Moisture Active Passive), high-frequency passive microwave sensors such as AMSR2 (Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer-2) and Chinese Fengyun series satellites, and active microwave sensors such as ASCAT (the Advanced Scatterometer) and Sentinel-1. Based on the observed passive (brightness temperature, TB) and/or active (backscatter coefficient) microwave signals, these platforms have developed corresponding retrieval algorithms and released soil moisture products to the public. (2) Merged soil moisture products estimated by blending multiple separately released microwave remotely sensed products. The most typical case is the CCI (Climate Change Initiative) project. (3) Model-derived soil moisture, including (but not limited to) NASA’s Global Land Data Assimilation System (GLDAS), NASA’s Modern-Era Retrospective analysis for Research and Applications (MERRA), and the European Center for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) Land Surface Reanalysis v5-Land (ERA5-Land) soil moisture products. There are different retrieval procedures, design accuracy, input datasets, and spatial-temporal resolution between the different soil moisture products, with their accuracy affected by different factors. For instance, the quality of satellite-based soil moisture products is hindered by retrieval algorithms, microwave instrument characteristics, topography, climate, and land cover conditions, while the model structure, input parameters, and atmospheric forcing errors are the main factors for the uncertainty of model-based products. The validation of soil moisture products is commonly based on comparison with reference data, which is assumed to be a good representation of ground truth, aiming to calculate their systematic and random errors and obtain quantitative statistics about the quality of soil moisture products. The random error variance of three collocated datasets can be estimated through triple collocation analysis (TCA), without the need for a single high-quality reference data, which is why TCA has been widely used in soil moisture validation studies. Inter-comparison between soil moisture products and dense in situ measurements (namely fiducial reference data or ground-truth) is currently the primary approach used to assess soil moisture products. Several scientific teams have established dedicated soil moisture networks, including the SMAP core validation sites and monitoring networks in the Tibetan Plateau.
research objective: This study is the first to use in situ measurements from the SMN-SDR to conduct a comprehensive evaluation of commonly used, multi-source soil moisture products. These results are expected to further promote the improvement of satellite- and model-based soil moisture products.
challenges: Considering the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, point-scale in situ measurements can only obtain precise information over a very small area. Accordingly, in situ measurements are usually too sparse to specifically describe the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales. The quality of satellite-based soil moisture products is hindered by retrieval algorithms, microwave instrument characteristics, topography, climate, and land cover conditions, while the model structure, input parameters, and atmospheric forcing errors are the main factors for the uncertainty of model-based products. The inevitable differences in spatial-temporal scale, and the construction of a dense network which is labor-intensive (e.g. repeated measuring) and costly, are the main challenges for ground-based evaluation. Although this approach is capable of solving scale issues and achieving a global-scale assessment, it can only provide relative conclusions between different soil moisture products, since these non-fiducial reference data may inherently contain unknown biases and uncertainties. The use of TCA requires some basic assumptions, which are often violated.
methods: In this study, in situ measurements of the SMN-SDR were used to evaluate 24 different soil moisture datasets grouped according to three categories: (1) single-sensor satellite-based products, (2) multi-sensor merged products, and (3) model-based products. Triple collocation analysis (TCA) was applied to all possible triplets to verify the reliability and robustness of the results.
dataset: The SMN-SDR currently consists of 34 stations within an area of ~10,000 km² (115.5 – 116.5°E, 41.5 – 42.5°N). At each station, five Decagon 5TM sensors were installed in a horizontal orientation at different measuring depths (3, 5, 10, 20, and 50-cm) to measure soil moisture and soil temperature. The nominal accuracy (and resolution) of the 5TM sensor are ± 3% m³/m³ (0.0008 m³/m³) for soil moisture and ± 1 K (0.1 K) for soil temperature. A total of 24 near-surface, coarse-resolution soil moisture datasets were used in this study, including 15 based on single-sensor satellite-based products (seven for L-band low-frequency passive microwave observations, seven for C/X-band higher-frequency passive microwave observations, and one for C-band active microwave observation), six based on multi-sensor merged products, and three based on land surface models.
findings: The results reveal that the latest Climate Change Initiative (CCI) -combined product (v06.1, merging extra low-frequency passive microwave data) had the best agreement with in situ measurements from the SMN-SDR, with the lowest ubRMSE (< 0.04 m³/m³) and highest R (> 0.6). Among all single-sensor retrieved soil moisture products, the Soil Moisture Active Passive (SMAP) products performed best in terms of R (> 0.6) and ubRMSE (close to 0.04 m³/m³), with the SMAP-MDCA (Modified Dual Channel Algorithm) being slightly better than the baseline SCA-V (Single Channel Algorithm-Vertical polarization). Importantly, the newly developed SMAP-IB product, which does not use auxiliary data, delivered the best bias statistics and higher VOD values compared with the drier SMAP retrievals, suggesting that the low VOD values (underestimated vegetation effects) may be the major factor causing the dry bias of SMAP products in this study area. It was also found that TCA may systematically overestimate the correlation and underestimate the ubRMSE of soil moisture products as compared with ground-based metrics. Redundant TCA-based metrics from multiple independent triplets could be averaged to increase the accuracy of final TCA estimates.

Definition.Question: What is a 'soil moisture product' in the context of hydrological and ecological research?
Definition.Answer: A soil moisture product refers to data obtained or derived for the purpose of measuring and analyzing soil moisture levels, which are critical for understanding the terrestrial water cycle and its impact on hydrological, ecological, and biogeochemical processes. These products can be generated from satellite observations, merged datasets, or model simulations, each with distinct methodologies and potential sources of error.

Definition.Question: How is 'triple collocation analysis (TCA)' used in soil moisture research?
Definition.Answer: Triple collocation analysis (TCA) is a statistical method employed to estimate the random error variance of three collocated datasets without the need for a high-quality reference data. In soil moisture research, it is used to validate soil moisture products by providing a means to calculate systematic and random errors, thus helping researchers assess the quality of these products.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced between conducting in situ soil moisture measurements and using model-based soil moisture products?
Comparison.Answer: In situ measurements face challenges such as spatial heterogeneity and the labor-intensive nature of constructing dense networks. In contrast, model-based products are affected by uncertainties arising from model structure, input parameters, and atmospheric forcing errors. Both approaches have inherent biases, but in situ measurements provide higher accuracy at specific locations while models offer broader coverage with potential accuracy limitations.

Interpretation.Question: How can the spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture be addressed in data collection to improve the accuracy of soil moisture datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture poses challenges because point-scale in situ measurements provide precise information over only a small area, and these measurements are usually too sparse to describe the spatial-temporal variation over large scales. Addressing this requires a dense network of measurements, which is labor-intensive and costly. Techniques like triple collocation analysis (TCA) can help verify the reliability of datasets without needing a single high-quality reference data, though they come with assumptions that may be violated.

Interpretation.Question: What are the main challenges faced in the calibration and validation of soil moisture datasets from satellite and model-based sources?
Interpretation.Answer: The main challenges in calibration and validation include retrieval algorithm limitations, microwave instrument characteristics, and environmental factors such as topography, climate, and land cover conditions that affect satellite-based products. For model-based products, the challenges include uncertainties in model structure, input parameters, and atmospheric forcing errors. Inter-comparison with dense in situ measurements is the primary method for validation.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the robustness and reliability of soil moisture products be enhanced through data collection and analysis methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Robustness and reliability can be enhanced by using in situ measurements from sensor networks like SMN-SDR to evaluate various soil moisture datasets, including single-sensor, multi-sensor merged, and model-based products. Triple collocation analysis is a method used to verify the reliability and robustness of datasets by estimating random error variance without needing a fiducial reference. Redundant TCA-based metrics from multiple independent triplets can be averaged to increase the accuracy of final estimates.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in obtaining accurate soil moisture data from in situ measurements over large scales?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: In situ measurements can only provide precise information over very small areas due to the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture. This results in a sparsity of data when trying to describe spatial-temporal variations over large scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do differences in spatial-temporal scale present challenges in the ground-based evaluation of soil moisture products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The inevitable differences in spatial-temporal scale between ground-based measurements and the datasets being evaluated pose challenges, as constructing a dense network for accurate evaluation is labor-intensive and costly.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the uncertainty in the accuracy of satellite-based and model-based soil moisture products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The accuracy of satellite-based soil moisture products is affected by retrieval algorithms, microwave instrument characteristics, topography, climate, and land cover conditions, while model-based product uncertainties stem from model structure, input parameters, and atmospheric forcing errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences on data accuracy when using in situ soil moisture measurements compared to satellite-based products in soil moisture studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: In situ soil moisture measurements provide precise information over a very small area, which can be too sparse to specifically describe the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales. Satellite-based products, while capable of covering large areas, are hindered by retrieval algorithms, microwave instrument characteristics, and environmental factors, which can affect their accuracy. The use of in situ measurements helps in validating and improving satellite-based soil moisture product accuracy.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of developing a wireless sensor network for monitoring soil moisture and temperature in a watershed region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of developing a wireless sensor network for monitoring soil moisture and temperature in a watershed region is to provide long-term ground reference data for the validation of satellite-derived and model-based soil moisture products, thereby improving their accuracy and reliability.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to employ triple collocation analysis in evaluating multi-source soil moisture datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to employ triple collocation analysis in evaluating multi-source soil moisture datasets because it allows for the estimation of random error variance among three collocated datasets, providing a method to verify the reliability and robustness of the results without the need for a single high-quality reference data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can soil moisture datasets from different sources be integrated and validated using in situ measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil moisture datasets from various sources, such as satellite-based, merged, and model-derived products, can be integrated and validated using in situ measurements by applying techniques like triple collocation analysis (TCA). This method helps estimate errors and assess the reliability of datasets by comparing them against in situ measurements, which serve as a reference ground truth for accuracy verification.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural challenges might researchers face when deploying a large-scale soil moisture sensor network, and how can these be addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Deploying a large-scale soil moisture sensor network involves challenges such as handling spatial heterogeneity, ensuring consistent data across scales, and managing costs. These can be addressed by implementing a dense network of sensors at multiple scales (large, medium, small) and using standardized equipment and procedures for data collection and calibration. Additionally, leveraging remote sensing data and models can complement ground-based measurements to enhance coverage and resolution.

Enablement.Question: What challenges must be addressed to enhance the spatial-temporal resolution of soil moisture data collection methods for large-scale applications?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, which makes point-scale in situ measurements too sparse for large-scale representation. Additionally, the construction of a dense sensor network is labor-intensive and costly. The accuracy of satellite-based products is affected by retrieval algorithms, instrument characteristics, and environmental factors, while model-based products are influenced by model structure and input errors.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be discrepancies in the accuracy of soil moisture products when compared to in situ measurements?
Expectation.Answer: Discrepancies in the accuracy of soil moisture products compared to in situ measurements can arise due to factors such as the retrieval algorithms used, the characteristics of microwave instruments, topography, climate conditions, and land cover. Additionally, model structure, input parameters, and atmospheric forcing errors also contribute to uncertainties in model-based products.

Expectation.Question: Why is it challenging to achieve a dense network for soil moisture data collection over large spatial scales?
Expectation.Answer: Achieving a dense network for soil moisture data collection over large spatial scales is challenging due to the labor-intensive and costly nature of constructing such networks. Moreover, in situ measurements typically provide precise information over small areas, which makes it difficult to describe spatial-temporal variations over larger scales.

Expectation.Question: Why do certain soil moisture products perform better in terms of correlation and bias statistics in specific study areas?
Expectation.Answer: Certain soil moisture products may perform better in terms of correlation and bias statistics in specific study areas due to factors such as the type of algorithm used, the frequency and orientation of microwave observations, and the consideration of vegetation effects. For example, the inclusion or exclusion of auxiliary data and the handling of vegetation optical depth can significantly influence the accuracy of the soil moisture retrievals.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what potential does triple collocation analysis (TCA) have in improving the validation process of soil moisture products, despite its inherent assumptions and limitations?
Judgmental.Answer: Triple collocation analysis offers a promising approach for improving the validation process of soil moisture products by allowing for error estimation without a single high-quality reference dataset. It enables relative comparison between different soil moisture products and provides a statistical basis for evaluating product quality. However, the potential of TCA is limited by its basic assumptions, which can be violated in practice, leading to systematic overestimation of correlation and underestimation of errors. Despite these limitations, TCA remains valuable for assessing the reliability and robustness of soil moisture datasets when applied carefully.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how soil moisture data from different sensors are merged to create a comprehensive dataset.
Assertion.Answer: Merged soil moisture products are estimated by blending multiple separately released microwave remotely sensed products, such as those from the Climate Change Initiative (CCI) project. This involves using retrieval algorithms to combine data from various sensors, like passive and active microwave observations, into a unified dataset.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges faced in validating soil moisture datasets using in situ measurements.
Assertion.Answer: Validation of soil moisture products is challenging due to the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, which makes point-scale in situ measurements too sparse to describe variations over large areas. The quality of satellite-based soil moisture products is affected by factors like retrieval algorithms and land cover conditions, while model-based products are influenced by model structure and input parameters.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how in situ soil moisture measurements can be used to improve satellite-based soil moisture products.
Assertion.Answer: In situ measurements provide fiducial reference data for validating and improving satellite-based soil moisture products. By comparing these measurements with remote sensing data, researchers can assess the systematic and random errors in satellite products, leading to enhancements in retrieval algorithms and product accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used to capture soil moisture and temperature variations across different spatial scales in a wireless sensor network.
Request/Directive.Answer: In a wireless sensor network covering approximately 10,000 square kilometers, data collection involves 34 stations equipped with Decagon 5TM sensors. These sensors measure soil moisture and temperature at five specified depths (3, 5, 10, 20, and 50 cm). The network comprises three sampling scales: large (100 km), medium (50 km), and small (10 km). Rain gauges are installed at 20 of these stations to record precipitation, helping to calibrate sensor data by analyzing soil samples for moisture content, bulk density, and soil texture.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and explain the challenges involved in ensuring the quality and reliability of soil moisture products derived from both satellite and in situ measurements.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include the spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, which limits the effectiveness of point-scale in situ measurements over large areas. The precision of satellite-based soil moisture products is compromised by retrieval algorithms, instrument characteristics, and environmental factors like topography and land cover. Model-based products face uncertainties due to model structure, input parameters, and atmospheric forcing errors. Ground-based evaluation involves labor-intensive and costly network deployment, and scale mismatches between datasets. Triple collocation analysis, often used for validation, requires assumptions that can be violated, impacting reliability.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding or refining soil moisture datasets to improve their applicability in large-scale hydrological and ecological studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: Strategies for expanding or refining soil moisture datasets include integrating in situ measurements with satellite observations to enhance spatial coverage and resolution. Developing more robust retrieval algorithms and validation techniques, like improved triple collocation analysis, can address biases and uncertainties. Establishing more dense and cost-effective sensor networks can provide more comprehensive ground-truth data. Additionally, leveraging multi-sensor merged products and refining model-based datasets through enhanced parameterization and assimilation techniques can improve dataset applicability for large-scale studies.
